Award.AwardTitle: Shape and data analysis using computational differential geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to rapid and vast data acquisition by modern technology, experiments and computer simulations, computational and data analytical approaches have become increasingly important for many important applications in science and engineering. An important but challenging task in data representation, analysis and understanding is to extract information of interest, which includes intrinsic geometric features and global structures from large data set. The aim of this project is to introduce advanced mathematical theories and analytical tools in differential geometry and translate them into efficient computation algorithms for data analysis.

The main effort of this project is to develop new mathematical models and computational tools for a few important but challenging tasks in 3D modeling and data analysis in higher dimensions. These models and tools will be utilized to extract and characterize geometric structures for data analysis in various applications. In particular, quasi-conformal map and conformal structure will be used for representation and analysis for surface maps and shape modeling. Intrinsic geometric differential operators, such as Laplace-Beltrami operator and its eigen-system, will be explored for point cloud analysis and manifold learning in high dimensions. Models, methods and computational tools developed in this project will be tested on benchmark data sets as well as real applications. Interdisciplinary applications and collaborations with computer scientists and statisticians will also be pursued.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational and data analytical approaches have become increasingly important for many important applications in science and engineering. A core issue underlying the common task of data analysis is how to extract, compute and analyze intrinsic geometrical quantities and global structures from data sets that are not only of large sizes but may also be embedded artificially in a very high dimensional space.  

In this project, novel mathematical models and computational tools have been developed for a few important but challenging tasks in 3D modeling and data analysis using advanced theories in differential geometry and partial differential equations. In particular, we developed general models for designing desirable surface maps and parametrization. Once these maps have been constructed, geometric features and global structures can be characterized by the map and can be utilized for shape analysis such as compression, reconstruction and recognition. 

Another effort in the project was on point cloud analysis. Point cloud is the most basic and simple way of sampling and representing geometric objects or information in high dimensions. For examples, three dimensional point clouds can be easily obtained through laser scanners for 3D modeling and shape representation, and a collection of images can be thought as a point cloud in high dimensions. However, the coordinates for the point cloud in the initial embedding could be far from intrinsic. This poses a challenge for shape comparison, recognition and classification. So one crucial task in many applications is point cloud registration. We have developed a a multiscale point cloud registration algorithm that can handle non-rigid transformation. Our algorithm has produced state-of-the-art performance on benchmark tests.

Research results and numerical algorithms developed from this project have been disseminated through journal publications and presentations at conferences, workshops, and seminars.

Education and training components were integrated in the research project at both undergraduate and graduate level to prepare young minds and new workforce in computational science for the future.
